Introduction

Molluscum contagiosum is a benign viral skin infection that presents with small, dome-shaped, flesh-colored papules with umbilicated centers.  Healthy children are most commonly affected, but molluscum contagiosum can also occur in adults, especially those who are immunocompromised or sexually active.

Pathophysiology and risk factors



Molluscum contagiosum is a common, benign skin infection caused by a poxvirus.  Transmission occurs through skin-to-skin contact or via contaminated fomites (eg, towels), with subsequent autoinoculation to additional sites.  The pathophysiology involves viral infection of epidermal cells, with subsequent replication within the cytoplasm.  This results in the enlargement of basal keratinocytes and the formation of characteristic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies.



Risk factors include young age (1-10), participation in contact sports, sexual activity, and cellular immunodeficiency (eg, HIV infection).

Clinical presentation



The lesions of molluscum contagiosum appear as firm, dome-shaped, flesh-colored papules with central umbilication (

image 1
).  Papules are small (2-5 mm in diameter), shiny, and usually asymptomatic but may be pruritic with mild surrounding inflammation.  Dermoscopy may reveal a white/yellow amorphous center.



Distribution of the lesions is dependent on age and immune status, as follows:



  • Children:  extremities, trunk, face (
    image 2
    ).  However, autoinoculation can lead to spread on any part of the body (except the palms and soles), including genitalia.
  • Adults:  lower abdomen, upper thighs (reflective of spread via sexual contact), genitalia (
    image 3
    )
  • Immunocompromised patients:  diffuse and often innumerable

Diagnosis



The diagnosis of molluscum contagiosum is typically clinical, based on characteristic appearance.



However, in patients with atypical lesions or in those who are immunocompromised, a biopsy may be performed to confirm the diagnosis.  In these cases, histopathology shows epidermal hyperplasia with molluscum bodies (large, eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusions made of poxvirus particles) (

image 4
).

Differential diagnosis



  • Flat warts (verruca plana) (
    image 5
    ):  flesh-colored or pink, scaly papules that lack central umbilication
  • Folliculitis (
    image 6
    ):  inflamed hair follicles that are often painful, pruritic, and/or pustular
  • Chickenpox (
    image 7
    ) (primary varicella-zoster virus infection):  acute, pruritic, vesicular rash that develops in successive crops; associated with systemic symptoms (eg, fever)
  • Basal cell carcinoma (
    image 8
    ):  typically an isolated, pearly nodule with associated telangiectasia; usually seen in older adults in sun-exposed areas
  • Sexually active patients/primarily genital lesions:
    • Condylomata lata (secondary syphilis):  pale/gray papules and plaques on mucosal surfaces (eg, genitalia, oral mucosa); often in association with constitutional symptoms (eg, lymphadenopathy) and maculopapular rash involving the palms/soles
    • Condylomata acuminata (
      image 9
      ):  painless, soft, often verrucous anogenital lesions that lack central umbilication
    • Genital herpes simplex virus infection (
      image 10
      ):  acute onset of grouped erythematous vesicles that evolve into painful ulcerations
  • Disseminated cryptococcosis (
    image 11
    ):  often seen in immunocompromised patients; typical variable morphology but may present as papules with umbilicated centers (biopsy required)

Prognosis and management



Molluscum contagiosum is self-limited in healthy patients, and lesions typically resolve in 6-12 months.



However, treatment is often considered in adults to reduce transmission to others, prevent autoinoculation, and/or improve cosmesis (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 1
).  Management options include curettage, cryotherapy (liquid nitrogen), and topical medications (eg, cantharidin, podophyllotoxin).



Management in healthy children is usually reassurance and observation because treatment options are often associated with local discomfort, bleeding, and sometimes scarring.



Patients with widespread or persistent lesions should undergo testing for HIV (and possibly other immune system disorders).  In addition, adolescents and adults with molluscum contagiosum of the genital area should undergo additional screening for sexually transmitted infections.

Summary



Molluscum contagiosum (

ðŸ“Š View Table: table 2
) is a benign viral infection that presents with small, dome-shaped, flesh-colored papules with central umbilication.  It typically self-resolves in 6-12 months, but treatment (eg, curettage, cryotherapy) is often recommended for adults to prevent spread to others and autoinoculation.  Immunodeficiency (eg, HIV) should be considered in those with widespread lesions.
